markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

journalstar.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website of The Lincoln Journal Star, the daily newspaper in Lincoln, Nebraska.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The site is owned by Lee Enterprises, a publicly traded company that owns more than 40 daily newspapers, including The St. Louis Post-Dispatch. Lee Enterprises newspapers generate revenue from advertising and subscriptions to their printed and digital editions.

Content

Journalstar.com’s cleanly designed home page concentrates on Lincoln, the state capital of Nebraska, and its surrounding area while also offering national and foreign news from The Associated Press. Other sections focus on business, opinion, lifestyle, and entertainment news. The home page has a prominent tab dedicated to the “Huskers,” covering sports teams at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

Credibility

The site offers original staff reporting on local and state issues, and wire service reports for national and international coverage. Stories typically have multiple named sources, and headlines that capture an article’s content. Photos, which include photo credits, are appropriate and complementary to stories.

The site appends corrections and clarifications to stories, noting in an appended correction box what change was made and why. Opinion is explicitly differentiated from news.

Transparency

The Contact Us page provides a street address and phone numbers for various departments. It also allows provides a phone number and email address for every staffer, from the top editor to a reporting intern.

History

The website went online by 1996. The newspaper is the descendant of several Nebraska newspapers that merged over the years. One of its predecessors, The Nebraska State Journal,  won the Pulitzer Prize for public service in 1949.

Written by:
Douglas Rowe

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Joyce Purnick
